topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack Community Virtual Installation and Configuration

body.p: This page provides instructions on how to perform a virtual installation of HPE Helion OpenStack Community onto a suitably specified and prepared single server. This cloud-in-a-box is designed to let you test the functionality of HPE Helion OpenStack Community. It is not intended to be used in a production environment to run real workloads; therefore, no support is available.

It is important to read through this page before starting your installation. Before you begin your installation, we recommend you review the complete Hardware and Software Requirements page. Note, however, that we have included the basic requirements on this page.

li.xref: Starting the undercloud, overcloud and test guest VM

section.title: Installation requirements
section.p: Before starting the installation, make sure your hardware and software the minimum requirements and are properly configured.

section.title: Hardware and system requirements
section.p: TripleO creates several large VMs as part of this virtual deployment process, make sure you meet the hardware requirements described in Community Hardware and Software Requirements.

section.title: Software requirements
section.p: To ensure a successful installation, you must meet the software requirements described in the Software configuration section in Community Hardware and Software Requirements.

section.title: Set DNS servers by default
section.p: After the installation, you can specify DNS servers on a per-subnet basis using the neutron subnet-create --dns-nameserver command.
Before installing, it is necessary to configure the DNS servers that will be used by dnsmasq as forwarders. Refer to Enabling name resolution from tenant VMs in the overcloudfor instructions.

section.title: About the installation process
section.p: There are a few things you should be aware of before you begin your HPE Helion OpenStack Community virtual installation.

li.p: The install will run until the demo completes loading the demo VM.

There are stalls loading images (1-2 mins) and building the undercloud (12 or more mins) and overcloud (at least that again). You can use a tool such as Virtual Machine Manager to monitor the installation of the nodes.
There are no restrictions imposed on external device name on the host system in virtual mode as the external interface is not used.
Filesystem checking on reboot is disabled by default for the seed, undercloud and overcloud nodes. We recommend periodically manually running fsck to verify filesystem integrity.

section.title: Installing HPE Helion OpenStack Community
section.p: Once you have met all of the hardware requirements and have completed the required tasks, you can begin your installation.
In the event you have trouble with the installation, review the Issues and troubleshooting and FAQ pages.

section.title: Unpacking the installation file
section.p: The virtual installation of HPE Helion OpenStack Community for a single server is provided as a compressed TAR file. This is a large file because it contains all of the machine images required for the seed VM, the undercloud, the overcloud, and a guest VM image.
Note: This install file does not fit on a memory stick formatted as FAT32. If you are planning to store the installation files on removable media, use something like NTFS.
To begin the installation:

li.p: Log in to your system as root.
Register and then log in to download the HPE Helion OpenStack Community virtual package from this site:

p.xref: HPE Helion OpenStack Community Edition Installation Package

li.p: The download file is named: Helion_Openstack_Community_V1.4.tar.gz
In the root user's home directory, create the work directory and extract the installation software to the work directory:

codeblock.codeph: mkdir work cd /work tar zxvf /{full path to downloaded file from step 2}/Helion_Openstack_Community_V1.4.tar.gz

section.p: This creates and populates a tripleo/ directory within the root/work/ directory.
